Belgia: 1590. July.
To our trusty & welbelovid Thomas Wilk
and Thomas Bodley esquiers, o
r
servitors in the
lowe Co
n
treyes
/.
fol.229v
Belgia : 1590:
page.lettertext:
fol.228r
Belgia: 1590
Belgia. 1590 22 July To M
r
Bodly
By the Queene.
Elizabeth R
Trusty and welbelovid, we greete you well, Ye shall understand that heer have
bene three Captens w
ch
heertofore have servid in
Camphire
namid
Joysse van den
Einde
,
Carselis Palant
, &
peter de Costere
, who have infourmid us that notw
t
stand
i
g
they have by the space of xviij yeeres or therabout
servid as Captens & born Armies
under the
Prince of Orenge
, in the garrison of Camphire to the c
o
tenta
o
n of the
Conte Maurice
and the
Stat
generall
. And for that whan o
r
late Cousin the
Erle of
Leycester
was gouverno
r
generall of those Provinc
, They were c
o
maunded by him
to
as leefully they thought he might doo, not to depart w
t
their c
o
panyes out of the
sayde Towne, w
ch
he did order for the safety of the same against the c
o
mon
ennemy, Yet ne
v
theles upon that pretext and upon som oth
r
demonstrations
of their good will toward
us and our service, they were by the States g
n
ral
refused to be contynued in their charges, And
whereas
were, as it appeered reproovid for
serving of us, though we had receavid the wholle co
u
try into o
r
protection,
Wherupon we caused it to be signified to the States g
n
rall by the
L. Willoughby
o
r
Lieute
n
t, and
Henry Killegrew
o
r
Counsaylo
r
there, That we had great cause
to myslyke such unkinde proceeding
of the said States g
n
rall against them
having no oth
r
matter wherw
t
they might be charged but that up
o
the commandem
t
of the Erle of Leycester that was Gouverno
r
g
n
rall of all the Provinces, they
did promise eyther by oth or otherwise to be serviceable to us, not therby having a
meaning eyther on o
r
parte to drawe them from the service of the publick cause of
the Co
u
trey, nether did they refuse to doo service for the defence of
e Town, And
upon these considerations the States seemed well content at o
r
motion for their
favo
r
, Wherupon followed an accorde by certain Articles betwixt the Conte Mauri
ce
& the States on the one partie, and the said captens on the parte by w
ch
the said
captens were restored, as it appeereth by the articles of the accorde, to the
favo
r
of the States, & of the Conte Maurice, and to their places of service
w
t
remission or rather oblivion of all thing
that had passed to have moovid
offence, Wherw
t
we found o
r
selfe very well satisfied, and accepted the same
thankfully for the said Captens behalfe & their c
o
panyes, But notw
t
standing
this accorde, the Cap
ns
doo now inform Us that c
o
trary to the same & to the
promise of the Conte Maurice under his hand writing, the said cap
ns
are by
the States & Conte deprived of their c
o
panyes, And their paym
t
upon their
fol.228v
Belgia 1590. July:
accompt
refused, W
ch
being true, We have good cause to think o
r
selves highly
touched in reputa
o
n. And th
r
fore not knowing any furder matter wh
r
upon
to judge but the informa
o
n of these captens, We have gra
n
ted to them that we will
cause the state of their cause to be declared to the States g
n
rall, & to require a
redresse therof, And for this purpose we doo by these p
n
t
will & require yo
u
to take all such informa
o
ns as the said captens bringing these o
r
l
re
s unto yo
u
shall give you wherby you may see the grounde of their c
o
plainte then made
unto us, to be apparantly true, And afterward
, w
t
as conven
[ien]
t speede as
you may, ye shall in o
r
name expressly require the Stat
g
n
ral to receave yo
r
informa
o
n as rec
o
mended
by us
from us, And moove them to observe thaccorde
& all tharticles that have bene made betwixt th
e
and the Conte Mauryce
w
t
the said cap
ns
upon the solicita
o
n of the L. Willoughby &
Henry
killegrew
w
ch
ye may alledge they can not violate w
t
out prejudice of o
r
hono
r
. And th
r
fore
we wish them to have more regarde therof, than of any particuler proffit
or oth
r
disple
s
r
toward
the said Captens, having bene men of good service,
Against wh
o
the worst they coulde alledge was that they by c
o
mandem
t
of their
own generall therle of Leyc
r
, did as all honest captens ought to have don,
promise eyth
r
by oth or oth
r
wise to keepe that Town safe, & allso to serve us, to
wh
o
the whole co
n
try was c
o
mitted in protecting. So as whatsoe
v
might be
c
o
strued to be service unto us ought not by any reason be c
o
ptid but
fittable
allso to the Wholle co
n
trey, & to the States g
n
rall. And so you may affirm
that we doo precisely accepte the servic
of all
sons that are or can be
don to us in those co
n
treis, ought to be in reason and judged to be to the
s
vice
& benefytt of the wholle states of those provinc
being in o
r
protection. for if
any oth
r
c
o
struction be made against any that have offred or shall offer to serve
us there, whilest we have the protection of those co
n
treis, We shall have cause
to think all o
r
forces & charg
bestowed upon th
e
to be ungratefully
receavid by them.
Given under o
r
Signet at o
r
Mannor of Grenwich the
xxij
th
of July
1590
in the xxxij
th
yeere of o
r
Raigne/
